overview: The purpose of this Act is to make the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent. [11] It also seeks to establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit. [11] Additionally, the bill requires the judiciary to submit a report to the legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for women's court in other circuits. [11]
appropriations: This measure appropriates an unspecified sum out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii for fiscal year 2025-2026 and an unspecified sum for fiscal year 2026-2027. [11] The funds are for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services, as well as the establishment of two temporary positions. [11] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary. [11]
assumptions_and_methodology: The provided documents do not specify the assumptions or methodology used to determine the necessary appropriation amounts, as the sums are left blank in the bill. [11] The goal of the pilot program is to divert participants from incarceration, support their success in the community, and reduce recidivism by implementing trauma-informed and evidence-based practices. [11] The services offered are intended to address areas such as trauma, family support, life-skills, and substance abuse treatment. [11]
agency_impact: The judiciary is tasked with making the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent. [11] It will also establish and supervise a new women's court pilot program within the third circuit Kona division. [11] The judiciary is also required to submit reports to the legislature regarding the new pilot program and the potential need for similar programs in other circuits. [11] [11]
economic_impact: The program aims to divert participants from incarceration, support their success in the community, and reduce recidivism. [11] It is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs. [11] The legislature finds that women offenders face unique barriers to success after incarceration, including being primary caregivers, having lower educational attainment, and lacking stable work history. [11]
policy_impact: This Act makes the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent by amending Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, to remove its repeal date. [11] It establishes a new, temporary three-year Women's Court Pilot Program within the Kona division of the Third Circuit. [11] [11] It also requires the judiciary to report on the need for and associated costs of a pilot program in the second and fifth circuits and the Hilo division of the third circuit. [11]
revenue_sources: The bill appropriates funds out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [11] The sums for fiscal years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027 are unspecified in this version of the bill. [11] No other revenue sources are identified in the provided documents. [11]
